snippet: Extremists are carving out pockets of territory for Islamist militants, posing what intelligence officials say may become the greatest security threat in the world today.
abstract: Extremists are carving out pockets of territory in Syria for Islamist militants, posing what intelligence officials say may become the greatest security threat in the world; counterterrorism officials worry that a new affiliate of Al Qaeda could be emerging.

byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. An employee of The New York Times contributed reporting from Raqqa, Syria.

lead_paragraph: Extremists are carving out pockets of territory for Islamist militants, posing what intelligence officials say may become the greatest security threat in the world today.

headline.main: As Foreign Fighters Flood Syria, Fears of a New Extremist Haven
headline.print_headline: Militants Flood Havens in Syria, Posing a Threat

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
keywords.name: subject
